```{r dosomef,cache=TRUE}
f <- function(a,b){
  if(a==0){return(0)}
  if(b==0){return(1)}
  if(a==b){return(1/2)}
  p <- a/(a+b)
  return(p*f(a,b-1) + (1-p)*f(a-1,b))
}

f(3,2) - 31/40

f(4,3) - 233/315
f(6,6)
f(6,7)
f(10,11)
```

$$P(a,b) =
\frac{a}{a+b}P(a,b-1) + \frac{b}{a+b}P(a-1,b)\qquad a,b>0$$

$$P(a,0)=1,a\geqslant 1,
P(0,b)=0,b\geqslant 1
$$

Looking at the recurrence
$x_{n+1}=\frac{n+1}{(n+3)!}+\frac{2x_n}{n+3}$, together with the
boundary condition that $x_1=\frac{5}{6}$, we can solve this to give

$$x_n = \frac{2^{n+2}-(n+2)}{(n+2)!}$$


Visually:

```{r plotn}
f <- function(n){(2^(n+2)-n-2)/factorial(n+2)}
n <- 1:10
plot(n,f(n),log='y')
```


$$x_{n+1}=\frac{n+1}{n+2}\frac{2^{n+3}-n-3}{(n+3)!} + 3x_n/(n+4)$$

This has solution, together with $x_1=\frac{23}{24}$, of

$$x_n=\frac{2\cdot 3^{n+3}+(n+3)(n+2-2^{n+4})}{2(n+3)!}$$

$$x_n=\frac{54\cdot 3^n-16(n+3)\cdot 2^n+(n+3)(n+2)}{2(n+3)!}$$

```{r testrecur}
f_exact <- function(n){(54*3^n-16*(n+3)*2^n+(n+3)*(n+2))/(2*factorial(n+3))}
f_exact(1:4) - c(23/24,31/40,1/2,82/315)
```

Using Stirling gives us that

$$s_n\sim\frac{27}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\left(\frac{3e}{n}\right)^n\cdot
n^{-7/2}$$

```{r exactapprox}
f_approx <- function(n){27/sqrt(2*pi)*(3/n)^n*exp(n)/n^(7/2)}
```

To compare them we will use a bespoke comparison function:

```{r definecomp}
comp <- function(x,y){c(LHS=x,RHS=y,diff=x-y)}
comp(f_exact(50),f_approx(50))
```

Try a larger value of $n$:

```{r}
f_exact(1000)
```

Above, see how `f_exact()` fails for $n=1000$, due to overflow.  It is
better to use logs, and some reorganisation:

```{r logexact}
f_approx_log <- function(n){log(27/sqrt(2*pi))+n+n*log(3/n)-(7/2)*log(n)}
f_exact_log <- function(n){
return(
        +(n+3)*log(3)
	+log(1 - (n+3)*(2/3)^(n+3) + (n+2)*(n+3)/3^(n+3)/2)
	-lfactorial(n+3)
	)
}
```

Now we can use larger values of $n$:

```{r trylargen}
comp(f_approx_log(100),f_exact_log(100))
comp(f_approx_log(1000),f_exact_log(1000))
```
and we see very close agreement with $n=1000$; Stirling is good!

Above we can set up a recurrence relation:

$$
y = x_n\cdot\frac{n-1}{2n} + 1\cdot\frac{n+1}{2n}
$$

$$
x_{n+1} = \frac{1}{2}\cdot\frac{n}{2n+1} + y\cdot\frac{n+1}{2n+1}
$$

Or altogether

$$
x_{n+1}= x_n\cdot\frac{n^2-1}{4n^2+2n} + \frac{2n^2+2n+1}{4n^2+2n}
$$


To solve these:

```
e = RSolve[{a[n+1] ==a[n]*(n^2-1)/(4*n^2+2*n) + (2*n^2+2*n+1)/(4*n^2+2*n),a[2]==5/6},a[n],n] // FullSimplify 
p = a[n] /. e 
f = p[[1]] 
```

This gives:

```
                                (9 + I Sqrt[3]) Sqrt[Pi]                                     1
       8 - 12 n + Gamma[1 + n] (------------------------ + 2 Hypergeometric2F1Regularized[1, - + n, 2 + n, 4])
                                     n       1                                               2
                                    4  Gamma[- + n]
   1                                         2
 -(--) -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   18                                                  -1 + n
```

NB: mathematica sometimes gets its knickers in a twist and gives an
equivalent, but much more complicated (!), result.  You just have to
try repeatedly and say a little prayer.  Using `FullSimplify`
sometimes helps.  Anyway, if the moon is full and the auspices are
favourable you get:

$$
\frac{1}{18(n-1)}
\left(
12n-8- \frac{(9+i\sqrt{3})\sqrt{\pi}\Gamma(n+1)}{4^n\Gamma(n+1/2)}-2\Gamma(n+1)\widetilde{{}_2F_1}(1,n+1/2;n+2;4)
\right)
$$

For some reason mathematica will not simplify further, but by hand
(and with a little bit of help from Milton and Irene) we find:

$$
\frac{1}{18(n-1)}
\left(
12n-8- \frac{(9+i\sqrt{3})\sqrt{\pi}\Gamma(n+1)}{4^n\Gamma(n+1/2)}-\frac{2{}_2F_1(1,n+1/2;n+2;4)}{n+1}
\right)
$$

$$
\frac{1}{9(n-1)}
\left(
6n-4- \frac{\sqrt{\pi}(9+i\sqrt{3})\Gamma(n+1)}{2\cdot 4^n\Gamma(n+1/2)}-\frac{{}_2F_1(1,n+1/2;n+2;4)}{n+1}
\right)
$$

$$
\frac{1}{9(n-1)}
\left(
  6n-4-
(9+i\sqrt{3})\frac{(n!)^2}{2(2n!)}
-\frac{{}_2F_1(1,n+1/2;n+2;4)}{n+1}
\right)
$$


$$
\frac{1}{9(n-1)}
\left(  6n-4-  \frac{9+i\sqrt{3}}{2{2n\choose n\,\,n}}-\frac{{}_2F_1(1,n+1/2;n+2;4)}{n+1}\right)
$$


(the tilde in $\widetilde{{}_2F_1}(1,n+1/2;n+2;4)$ means the
_regularized_ ${}_2F_1$ Gauss hypergeometric function).  The
combinatorical term $\frac{9+i\sqrt{3}}{2{2n\choose n\,\,n}}$ tends to
zero quite quickly, going as $\sqrt{n}4^{-n}$ (from Stirling).  The
hypergeometric term is harder.  First, note that it is evaluated _on_
the cut line (which goes from $1+0i$ to $\infty$ along the real axis);
the hypergeometric function is defined on the cut line as being
continuous from below.  In any event, the imaginary component tends to
zero as $n\longrightarrow\infty$.

Using 

$$
\newcommand{\Fmn}[2]{\operatorname{{}_{#1}F_{#2}}}
\newcommand{\ft}{\Fmn{2}{1}}
\newcommand{\four}[4]{\frac{\Gamma\left(#1\right)\Gamma\left(#2\right)}{\Gamma\left(#3\right)\Gamma\left(#4\right)}}
\ft\left(a,b;c;z\right)
= \four{c}{b-a}{b}{c-a}\left(-z\right)^{-a}\ft\left(a,1-c+a;1-b+a;\frac{1}{z}\right)
+\four{c}{a-b}{a}{c-b}\left(-z\right)^{-b}\ft\left(b,1-c+b;1-a+b;\frac{1}{z}\right)
$$

With $a=1,b=n+1/2,c=n+2,z=4$ we find that

$$
\ft(1,n+\frac{1}{2};n+2;4)=\four{n+2}{n-\frac{1}{2}}{n+\frac{1}{2}}{n+1}(-4)^{-1}\ft(1,-n;\frac{3}{2}-n;\frac{1}{4})
+
\four{n+2}{1/2-n}{1}{3/2}(-4)^{-n-1/2}\ft\left(n+\frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{2};n+\frac{1}{2};\frac{1}{4}\right)
$$

In the above, the first term on the RHS is
$-\frac{n+1}{2(2n-1)}\ft(1,-n;\frac{3}{2}-n;\frac{1}{4})$.  Note that
AMS-15.4.13, viz

$$
\ft(a,b;a+b+1/2;x)=2^{a+b-1/2}\Gamma(1/2+a+b)x^{(1/2-a-b)/2}P^{1/2-a-b}_{a-b-1/2}\left[(1-x)^{1/2}\right]
$$

with $a=1$,$b=-n$, $x=1/4$ gives

$$
\ft(1,-n;3/2-n;1/4)=2^{1/2-n}\Gamma(3/2-n)x^{(n-1/2)/2}P^{n-1/2}_{n+1/2}(\sqrt{3}/2)
$$

. . . but this does not seem to help, as all the formulae in chapter 8
(e.g. 8.1.2) give $P^\mu_\nu(z)$ in terms of $\ft()$.  There does not
seem to be any simplification available for Legendre functions with
some relation between $\mu$ and $\nu$, e.g. $P^\mu_\mu(x)$ or
$P^\mu_{\mu\pm 1}(x)$.

For the second term, we can use the identity $\ft(a,b;b;z)=(1-z)^{-a}$
to get

$$
\frac{\Gamma(2+n)\Gamma(1/2-n)}{\sqrt{\pi}/2}\cdot\frac{(-4)^{-n}}{\sqrt{-4}}\cdot\left(1-\frac{1}{4}\right)^{1/2}
$$


Now we have $\Gamma(1/2-n) =
\frac{(-4)^n\sqrt{\pi}}{2}\cdot\frac{\Gamma(n)}{\Gamma(2n)}$; and also
we know that

$\Gamma(2n)/\Gamma(n)^2=(n/2)\cdot{2n\choose n\,\,n}$, or
$\frac{\Gamma(n)}{\Gamma(2n)} = \frac{2}{n\Gamma(n){2n\choose n\,\,n}}$.

So $\Gamma(1/2-n)=\frac{(-4)^n\sqrt{\pi}}{n\Gamma(n){2n\choose
n\,\,n}}$.  So overall the second term becomes, after simplification,

$$-i\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\cdot\frac{n+1}{2n\choose n\,\,n}$$


Going back to the mathematica expression we have

$$
\frac{\ft(1,n+1/2;n+2;4)}{n+1}=
-\frac{\ft(1,-n;3/2-n;1/4)}{2(2n-1)}
-\frac{i\sqrt{3}}{2{2n\choose n\,\,n}}
$$



$$
\frac{1}{9(n-1)}
\left(6n-4-  \frac{9+i\sqrt{3}}{2{2n\choose n\,\,n}}-(
-\frac{\ft(1,-n;3/2-n;1/4)}{2(2n-1)}
-\frac{i\sqrt{3}}{2{2n\choose n\,\,n}})
\right)
$$


$$
\frac{1}{9(n-1)}
\left(6n-4-  \frac{9}{2{2n\choose n\,\,n}}+\frac{\ft(1,-n;3/2-n;1/4)}{2(2n-1)}
\right)
$$







```{r}
library("hypergeo")
f <- function(n){
(6*n-4-9/(2*choose(2*n,n)) + hypergeo(1,-n,3/2-n,1/4)/(2*(2*n-1))) / (9*(n-1))
}
f(2)-5/6
f(3)-31/40
f(4)-26/35
f(5)
f(6)
f(100)
```



```{r calcarray,cache=TRUE}
options(digits=4)
n <- 40
A <- matrix(NA,n,n)
A[1,] <- 1/factorial(seq_len(n) + 1)
A[,1] <- 1-A[1,]
for(i in 2:n){
  for(j in 2:n){
     A[i,j] <- i/(i+j)*A[i,j-1] + j/(i+j)*A[i-1,j]
  }
}
```

```{r plotA}
matplot(A,type='l',lty=1)
matplot(log(A/(1-A)),type="l",ylim=c(-10,10),lty=1,main="round-off error for p ~= 1")
contour(log(A),asp=1)
contour(log(A/(1-A)),asp=1)
matplot(A + t(A)-1)
N <- seq_len(n-1)
plot(N,A[cbind(N,N+1)])
delta <- A[cbind(N+1,N)]-0.5
plot(N,log(delta),ylim=c(-3,0))
points(N,-log(N)/2-1/sqrt(2),type='l')
approx <- exp(-1/sqrt(2))/sqrt(N)
plot(N,approx/delta)
```
